awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a State-of-the-Art Water Isotope Analyzer to Monitor Changes in the Coupled Climate System and Water Cycle at High Latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alaska Anchorage's Environment and Natural Resources Institute (ENRI) stable isotope laboratory has a long history of serving a broad research community and fostering collaborations among academic and government scientists studying the Arctic. With this MRI award, the investigators will replace retired equipment with the purchase a new instrument to analyze the stable isotopes of hydrogen and oxygen with high precision on a fee-for-service basis. As components of water molecules, isotopes of hydrogen and water serve as valuable tracers within the coupled climate system and water cycle, and isotope data can be used to understand changes in air, water, and ice over time and space. In addition to supporting a wide range of scientific studies, the laboratory hosts tours for high school and undergraduate students and trains undergraduate and graduate students in analytical techniques as part of their coursework.

The investigators will purchase a new Picarro L2130-I cavity ring-down spectroscopy water isotope analyzer to replace retired, early models that have processed more than 50,000 water samples. Analytical capability will be expanded by adding a new vaporizer and autosampler and add to the suite of instruments operated and maintained in the Environment and Natural Resources Institute Stable Isotope Laboratory. This lab, the only of its kind in Southcentral Alaska, produces data that are used by academic and government scientists in Alaska and beyond to understand the hydrologic cycle and climate in the Arctic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award provided funds to replace two retired Picarro L1102-i water isotope analyzers with one new Picarro L2130-i water isotope analyzer in the Environment and Natural Resources Institute?s Stable Isotope Laboratory (ENRI SIL) at the University of Alaska Anchorage (UAA).  The new L2130-i has been providing high-quality water isotope data to the research community since its installation in the early spring of 2019.  It has also provided two ENRI SIL Managers with the opportunity to become adept in the use of cutting-edge water isotope technology.  As of December 2021, the L2130-i is fully operational with no end in sight.  

The climates of arctic and boreal regions are changing at rates much greater than observed at lower latitudes.  Arctic sea ice decline is exceeding forecasts and accelerating.  Glaciers and ice sheets are losing mass, while stream discharge and freshwater flux to the ocean are increasing.  The loss of arctic sea ice is leading to changes in storm tracks that have further accelerated the sea ice decline. The L2130-i in the ENRI SIL measures stable isotopes of oxygen and hydrogen in water, which serve as valuable tracers of the coupled climate system and water cycle. 

The L2130-i has supported the water isotope analysis needs of a wide range of research projects.  One example is the National Science Foundation EPSCoR project, "Fire and Ice".  The Fire and Ice project uses water isotope data to investigate freshwater influxes across a gradient of glaciated watersheds to the Gulf of Alaska, to assess the spatial extent of fresh water mixing in the intertidal zone and its effects on near-shore marine ecosystems. 

The Environment and Natural Resources Institute?s Stable Isotope Laboratory (ENRI SIL) at the University of Alaska Anchorage (UAA) is an important provider of water isotope data to academic and federal agency researchers in Alaska, the lower-48 and throughout the world.  The ENRI SIL is the only stable isotope laboratory in southcentral Alaska, where it serves the sample analysis needs of researchers at UAA and Alaska Pacific University, along with agency scientists at the United States Geological Survey, United States Forest Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, National Park Service and Alaska Department of Fish and Game, all of whom have their regional headquarters in Anchorage.  The high-precision water isotope analytical capacity provided by the L2130-i is helping to ensure that the ENRI SIL will continue to act as a catalyst for collaborative university-agency research in southcentral Alaska.

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: Patrick F Sullivan

Image
  • Picarro L2130-i in the ENRI SIL
    L. Wienkers
    Public Domain
    Patrick F Sullivan
    Picarro L2130-i in the ENRI SIL
